1140.14.text:
JOHN OSBORNE: So this
Power Breath workshop

1141.93.text:
is a five-day workshop
that we offer for vets.

1144.36.text:
It's a combination
of yoga, meditation,

1146.77.text:
and a very specialized
form of rhythmic breathing

1150.19.text:
called the Sudarshan
Kriya yoga technique.

1152.99.text:
Most people at Google
know that breathing

1155.96.text:
is one of the main
sources of energy, right?

1158.26.text:
You can live for several weeks
without food, several days

1161.90.text:
without water, but you
can't live for very long

1165.56.text:
So breath is, we all know,
a major source of energy.

1168.00.text:
It's also a major
part of our health.

1169.85.text:
About 80% of the toxins
that leave the body

1171.82.text:
leave the body
through the breath.

1173.24.text:
But there's a third
mysterious aspect

1175.25.text:
to the breath that allows this
workshop to be very powerful.

1178.97.text:
And that is that the breath
is a very powerful link

1182.13.text:
between the mind and the
body and the emotions.

1184.84.text:
How many people have
been at a meeting

1186.42.text:
at Google where you
know that somebody's not

1188.88.text:
having a very good day
or not having a very

1190.67.text:
good time at the meeting,
because you look over,

1194.94.text:
And you think, in
about five seconds,

1196.58.text:
I don't want to be in

1198.37.text:
How many people have had an
experience in or out of Google

1200.66.text:
When you see that, emotions
change and the breath changes.

1205.02.text:
We see the breath
change and we think, OK,

1208.89.text:
Any mothers here
with small children?

1212.71.text:
And so have you ever sung
a lullaby to your child,

1214.93.text:
and you see the breath getting
slower and getting longer,

1217.78.text:
and you're thinking,
in 30 more seconds,

1219.78.text:
my child is finally

1223.49.text:
And it's that link that we use
in the Power Breath workshop.

1226.29.text:
Because most of the time, we
notice the emotional change,

1229.93.text:
and then we notice the change
in the rhythm of the breath.

1234.05.text:
But we teach specific
rhythms of the breath

1236.08.text:
to the vets, which allow them
to come to a center place

1239.19.text:
no matter what else is
going on in their life,

1241.20.text:
and to come back in

1243.02.text:
These are people
that are trapped

1244.17.text:
in their memories and their
physiological reactions

1246.87.text:
I said at the
beginning, these are

1248.29.text:
people that run red
lights in Los Angeles,

1251.81.text:
because they're afraid there's
a bomb at the side of the road.

1254.39.text:
They're not able to live
in the present at all.

1258.33.text:
Most of us, our mind swings
from the past to the future,

1261.30.text:
and sometimes lives in
the present, hopefully.

1263.48.text:
But for them, their mind
is trapped in the past.

1265.77.text:
And these rhythmic breaths, the
[? Sky ?] Sudarshan Kriya yoga

1269.13.text:
breath work not only
brings them to the present

1272.18.text:
but allows the body
naturally to begin

1274.34.text:
to let go of trauma and
stress-- not just in that day,

1279.46.text: And they refer to some research.

1281.33.text:
There's just been one pilot
study done on this program.

1283.90.text:
It was done at the Center for
the Study of the Healthy Mind,

1286.73.text:
Dr. Richard Davidson--
some of you may know him.

1288.73.text:
I think he's actually
come and spoken

1290.27.text:
at Google-- at the
University of Wisconsin.

1292.48.text:
And that research showed,
with a control group

1295.35.text:
of 10 vets taking the course and
10 vets doing something else,

1298.50.text:
over a period of seven
days, that their symptoms

1301.32.text:
of Post-Traumatic Stress lowered
on an average of 40% to 50%.

1306.48.text:
But what is also interesting
is that when they measured them

1308.98.text:
six months later, the
symptoms were still lower.

1311.38.text:
And when they measured
them a year later,

1314.71.text:
Now, it's still too early to
know what that pilot means.

1317.19.text:
But it means generally
that their experience

1320.02.text:
of their own trauma,
the sleeplessness,

1321.99.text:
the hyper-arousal,
the flash to anger

1326.24.text:
And whether or not they
practiced these techniques

1331.94.text:
was still lower after six
months and after a year.

1335.35.text:
So now, eight years later,
we've taught about 1,000 vets.

1338.36.text:
And we are training teachers
as fast as we can, because,

1344.00.text:
as I said earlier, there's
300,000 to 400,000 people

1349.44.text:
And a lot of them don't want to
be on drugs, because the drugs

1352.94.text:
have a lot of side effects,
and they mask the symptoms,

1355.87.text:
but they don't really
cure the cause.

1358.37.text:
And they don't want
to go-- especially

1360.18.text:
if they're still in the
service for-- there's

1362.05.text:
a great stigma for going
for psychiatric care.

1364.69.text:
So programs like these
provide an alternate way

1367.72.text:
of dealing with the
Post-Traumatic Stress.

1369.48.text:
And as I said earlier,
it's something

1371.02.text:
that they can do by
themselves for themselves.

1373.25.text:
So it's a program that
the soldiers like a lot.

1382.38.text:

1406.58.text:

And we're going to

And just close your eyes and

1531.90.text:
Let's sit comfortably with

1535.52.text:
spine straight, palms up

1541.83.text:
Let's begin by taking a normal
breath in through the nose.

1553.44.text:
Begin by finding ourselves
in this environment,

1562.18.text:
listening to all the noises

1570.84.text:
from the other room, the hum

1588.25.text:
And feel that connection

1627.44.text:
Now perhaps you're feeling

1655.52.text:
Become aware of
your physical body.

1675.71.text:
It may be feeling
a little agitated.

1678.78.text:
There could be some
aches or pains or twinges

1681.45.text: in certain parts of the body.

1685.19.text:
Just be with your body

1718.56.text:
Innocently, put your
awareness on your right foot.

1865.68.text:
Allow your awareness
to flow like a river

1881.05.text:
The top of your head to
the soles of your feet.

1963.35.text:
Just watch them flow by
like they're in a river,

1966.15.text:
and don't try to control them
or judge them in any way.

2010.33.text:
Underneath our thoughts,
we all have feelings.

2014.06.text:
Allow yourself to become
aware of your feelings.

2043.19.text:
Happy feelings, sad
feelings, anxious feelings,

2052.32.text:
Whatever kind of feelings
are there, just observe them.

2104.35.text:
Underneath the bodily

2107.26.text:
and the feelings, there's a

2114.87.text: Deep and silent like an ocean.

2118.40.text:
Allow yourself to drop into
that deeper, silent place.

2147.72.text:
In that deep, silent
place, there's

2150.93.text: a well of peace and joy.

Once again, put your

2301.81.text:
Become aware of

2334.99.text:

2359.62.text:

you can slowly and

2443.77.text:

2448.68.text: for your service to our country.

2450.89.text:
I was talking to someone who

2453.38.text:
and they were trying to
decide whether they wanted

2457.67.text:
to contribute and
support our organization.

2462.25.text:
And they said, well, you know,
I give to my home country.

2464.91.text:
I give lots of things

2466.62.text:
And I said, well, while
you're here in Silicon Valley,

2469.90.text:
it's not your home country
that's protecting you,

2471.94.text:
it's the American
servicemen and women

2475.32.text:
And coming back,
they're the people

2477.27.text: that can really use our help.

2479.36.text:
They've stuck their
necks out for us,

2482.63.text:
And it's now time for us
to be able to help them

2488.67.text:
I want to tell you just one

2492.42.text:
came up for me during

2494.38.text:
that I've been lucky enough to

2496.97.text: why I'm here at Google today.

2501.81.text:
He wasn't in this film,
but he was a dog handler

2505.09.text:
in Vietnam, which meant that he
had a dog that he worked with.

2507.68.text:
And they'd send the dogs
into the Viet Cong tunnels,

2510.09.text:
and they'd come
out the other end.

2512.81.text:
And one day, he sent
his dog into a tunnel,

2514.63.text:
and a whole bunch of
Viet Cong came out

2516.25.text:
the other end of the tunnel, and
they started shooting at him.

2518.56.text:
He wasn't really a combatant,
but he had a weapon,

2521.02.text:
And when they did
the body count,

2522.54.text:
he had a special
weapon, so he knew

2524.68.text:
who had been killed by other
people and who he had killed.

2527.10.text:
And one of the
people he had killed,

2532.17.text:
And on the last day of
this five-day course,

2534.00.text:
he came up to me and he
grabbed me and he shook me,

2538.52.text:
And he said, she's
gone, she's gone.

2543.32.text:
And he said, that girl
I killed, he said, she's

2545.28.text:
been in my dreams every
night for the last 40 years.

2548.52.text:
And last night was the first
night I slept through the night

2551.02.text:
and she didn't come
back in my dreams.

2552.44.text:
So imagine what it would be
like to live a life like that,

2554.98.text:
and then to live a life
free of that kind of thing.

2557.64.text:
Another Vietnam vet I taught,
when he did this breathing

2561.00.text:
for the first time, he
experienced a memory

2564.06.text:
that he had repressed
ever since Vietnam.

2566.59.text:
He had forgotten
completely about it

2568.09.text:
where a hand grenade had
come down in a foxhole

2571.29.text:
that he was in, and he had
thrown the hand grenade up

2573.50.text:
in the air, and saved
himself and his comrades

2577.12.text:
And it exploded about
30 feet above his head.

2579.79.text:
And he said, during
the breathing,

2581.21.text:
not only did he smell the
sulfur of the grenade--

2583.77.text:
I think that's sort of
an interesting fact.

2585.80.text:
He said, but there was
a whole part of his mind

2588.20.text:
that had been trapped behind
this repressed memory, he said,

2590.86.text:
that started to come
out during the course.

2592.24.text:
He had access to it for
the first time in 40 years.

2594.58.text:
And he got actually a little
angry at the instructors.

2596.83.text:
He said, where were
you 40 years ago?

2598.37.text:
He said, my whole
life would have

2599.75.text:
been different had I had
access to this particular part
